Title: Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day

Orientation: PAST

Mechanic: Buy 12 pints, get a stamp in your Guinness passport for every pint, , walk away with a Guinness T-shirt and your share in Sir Guinness the racehorse
Objective: Drive pint velocity and dwell time in priority Guinness pubs across St Patrick's week.
Primary KPI: +12% Guinness draught volume vs LY across participating pubs
SKU focus: Guinness Draught on tap
Activation channels: On-premise venues, Liquor retail, Digital-first activation
Retail focus: On-premise venues, Liquor retail, Digital-first activation
Reward posture: Assured (guaranteed reward)
Retail notes: Prioritise high-volume Irish pubs in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane.
Promotion type: GWP
Regulated category: Yes
Age gate: Yes
Calendar theme: St Patrick's Day
Media: In-store, Social, Radio, Digital, Influencer, Retail Media
GWP: Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Trigger: 12 | Cap: UNLIMITED
Assured value: Everyone gets Guinness T-SHIRT, ONE share in Sir Guinness THE RACEHORSE
Entry: Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar
Ops: NONE • INSTANT • ZERO
Distinctive assets: Visual: Black pint silhouette, Gold harp, Surge-and-settle cascade | Verbal: Made of More, Good things come to those who wait | Ritual: Two-part pour, First sip moustache moment

Buyer tensions: ]

framing.content:
Where the Demand Is

Autumn in Australia is a key period for beer consumption, particularly with events like St Patrick's Day driving pub attendance. The Australian liquor market is seeing a resurgence in on-premise consumption, with craft beers and authentic experiences gaining traction (Source: nielseniq.com). Guinness, with its strong brand presence, is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend. The focus is on increasing pint velocity and dwell time in pubs during St Patrick's week, aiming for a 12% increase in Guinness draught volume compared to last year (Source: brief).

Who It’s For & What Stops Them

This promotion targets Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout enthusiasts who seek a guaranteed St Patrick's Day story. They value authentic Irish rituals and enjoy collecting Guinness merchandise, wearing it the same night (Source: brief). A key barrier is the cost of living pressures, which influence consumers to seek value in their purchases (Source: drinkstrade.com.au). Another mindset is the social drinker who wants to participate in the Guinness ritual without the hassle of complex promotions.

Competitor Map

Kilkenny and Murphy's are direct competitors, both offering Irish-themed experiences. Kilkenny focuses on enhancing the drinking experience with exclusive deals on glassware, while Murphy's leverages its Irish pub atmosphere (Source: kilkennydesign.com). Local craft stout taps also pose a threat, appealing to consumers seeking unique, locally brewed options. Guinness stands out with its iconic two-part pour and the theatre surrounding its consumption, which competitors struggle to replicate.

Brand Lens (truth, codes to lean/break)

Guinness is synonymous with the theatre of the two-part pour and St Patrick's Day rituals. The brand's rewards program enhances loyalty, offering exclusive experiences and merchandise (Source: guinness.com). Visually, the black pint silhouette and gold harp are distinctive assets. Verbally, phrases like "Made of More" and "Good things come to those who wait" reinforce the brand's premium yet convivial tone. The campaign should lean into authentic Irish experiences and guaranteed value promotions, avoiding generic beer promotions and overused clichés.

The Idea As It Stands

The current promotion involves buying 12 pints of Guinness, collecting stamps in a passport, and redeeming them at the bar for a Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse. This mechanic is designed to drive repeat visits and increase dwell time in pubs. However, the value proposition may need enhancement to meet consumer expectations for assured value.

Proposition Candidates

1. "Buy 12, Wear the Legend" – Emphasize the immediate reward of a Guinness T-shirt.
2. "Sip, Stamp, Score" – Highlight the simplicity and certainty of the reward.
3. "Raise a Pint, Back a Winner" – Connect the Guinness experience with the excitement of backing a racehorse.

Hooks (2–6 words)

Back a Winner
Sip, Stamp, Score
Wear the Legend
Raise a Pint

What We’d Lean On

The campaign should leverage Guinness' distinctive assets, such as the two-part pour and the surge-and-settle cascade. The focus should be on creating a memorable St Patrick's Day experience that aligns with the brand's premium positioning. The assured value of the promotion must be clear and compelling to overcome cost-related barriers.

Hypotheses for Evaluation

1. Increasing the visibility of the Guinness T-shirt as a reward will drive higher engagement.
2. Simplifying the redemption process will enhance participation and repeat visits.
3. Emphasizing the connection between Guinness and the racehorse share will create a unique narrative that differentiates from competitors.

Entry/Redemption (from brief): Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar

The entry mechanic is straightforward, encouraging repeat visits and engagement with the brand. However, the perceived value of the reward should be evaluated to ensure it meets consumer expectations and drives the desired increase in pint velocity.

adequacy.fix: Change-from: n/a on ~$20. → Change-to: ≥$5 or ≥10% of ASP, or pivot to a premium GWP with clear RRP.

simplicity.why: Some admin implied (fields/proof or wait time).
simplicity.fix: Keep claim one-screen; limit fields; good OCR; publish timelines.

certainty.fix: Fix adequacy first; certainty only works if value feels worth it.

salience.why: Number reads small; lacks stopping power.
salience.fix: Round up or pivot to premium GWP with explicit RRP.

talkability.fix: Add a brand-right experiential or symbolic angle.

retailerFit.why: Ensure any adjudication is central; ship pre-packed POS.
retailerFit.fix: Keep staff script ≤5s; no in-store adjudication.

brandFit.fix: Lock line and visuals to distinctive assets and the brand’s functional truth.

recommendations: Change-from: n/a on ~$20. → Change-to: ≥$5 or ≥10% of ASP, or pivot to a premium GWP with clear RRP.

brand.summary: Guinness is a stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in the 18th century. It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

shopperTensions.text: Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout fans are seeking memorable St Patrick's Day experiences, creating a demand for unique in-pub promotions and storytelling opportunities.
The cost of living pressures and inflation are impacting alcohol purchasing decisions, with consumers seeking value in their beverage choices.

retailerReality.text: Pubs and hotels are priority retailers for Guinness, emphasizing the importance of on-premise strategies to drive pint velocity during St Patrick's week.
The Mercantile Hotel, Sydney's oldest Irish pub, offers $8 Guinness pints, highlighting the competitive pricing strategies in on-premise channels.

competitorMoves.text: Kilkenny, also under Diageo's umbrella, offers a nitrogenated Irish cream ale, presenting a direct competitor within the same portfolio.
Kilkenny's promotional strategies, such as offering exclusive deals on glassware, suggest a focus on enhancing the drinking experience.

categorySignals.text: The Australian liquor industry is adapting to new consumer trends, with a focus on craft beers and sustainability, providing growth opportunities for brands like Guinness.

brand.summary: Guinness is a stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in the 18th century. It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

brand.summary: Guinness is a stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in the 18th century. It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

evaluation.content:
Verdict — This is a NO-GO until the mechanics are recalibrated to meet consumer value expectations amidst rising cost-of-living pressures, ensuring the Guinness promotion aligns with the demand for unique and memorable experiences during St Patrick’s Day. Why it works — The campaign leverages Guinness’ iconic brand presence and taps into the festive allure of St Patrick’s Day, fulfilling the consumer’s desire for authentic Irish experiences and guaranteed rewards (Source: brief). Where it breaks — The current mechanic of buying 12 pints for a T-shirt and racehorse share lacks immediate gratification and perceived value, a misalignment with consumers’ expectations for instant rewards and value amid economic constraints (Source: drinkstrade.com.au). Fix it — Introduce an immediate and visible reward element such as the 'Golden Tap' surprise, ensuring each pint carries the potential for instant gratification, thereby enhancing consumer engagement and perceived value. Retailer reality — This activation promises increased foot traffic and pint velocity without burdening store teams, as the mechanics rely on digital consumer interactions and zero additional staff efforts, seamlessly integrating into pub operations. Tighten — Ensure every pint purchase triggers an immediate chance for a collectible or surprise win to enhance perceived value. Stretch — Implement a digital passport that logs pint purchases and rewards automatically, removing any redemption hassle. Hook upgrade — “Raise a Pint, Back a Winner” lacks the immediate reward clarity and excitement that consumers crave; emphasizing the aspect would better capture attention. Hook shortlist — - “Sip and Score Big” - “Every Pint, A Winning Moment” - “Instant Cheers, s” - “Pour to Play, Win Today” - “Pint, Play, Prize” Measurement — Track increase in pint sales per pub during the promotional period. Pack line — “Pour to Play, Win Today.” Staff line — “Every pint could be a winner!”

Key campaign-specific directives:
• shopper tension: Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout fans are seeking memorable St Patrick's Day experiences, creating a demand for unique in-pub promotions and storytelling opportunities. (brief)
• shopper tension: The cost of living pressures and inflation are impacting alcohol purchasing decisions, with consumers seeking value in their beverage choices. (drinkstrade.com.au)
• brand truth: Guinness has successfully leveraged its distinctive brand voice and consumer insights to become one of Diageo's strongest performers, with a 14% increase in net sales and a notable 24% rise in female drinkers. (warc.com)

brand.summary: Guinness is a stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in the 18th century. It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

ui.priorOpinion: As autumn’s golden glow descends on Australia, St Patrick’s Day emerges as a beacon for Guinness, a cultural moment ripe for disruption. The Australian liquor market, robust and thriving, presents a stage where Guinness can dance its two-part pour and cascade its black-and-gold magic. With nearly 70% of Australians indulging in alcohol, the timing is impeccable to capture the hearts and palates of stout enthusiasts (Source: my.nzte.govt.nz). Today, Guinness meets its moment by weaving its brand truth into the fabric of St Patrick’s Day. The promotion promises more than a pint; it offers a story. The Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse are not mere giveaways; they are tangible tokens of pride and participation. Yet, the challenge lies in the high barrier of entry—12 pints—a steep climb in Sydney’s costly beer landscape, 60% pricier than New York (Source: news.com.au). The cultural timing aligns perfectly, but the execution demands a recalibration. Our improvement plan is clear: pivot to a more accessible mechanic. By shifting from 12 pints to a single-pint purchase, we democratize the experience. Each pint becomes a passport, a digital stamp collected with ease. This simplicity not only reduces hassle but aligns with the assured value ethos that Guinness embodies. The Evaluation suggests a premium GWP with explicit RRP, enhancing perceived value and engagement. For retailers, this streamlined approach is a boon. No additional staff lift, no complex adjudication. The digital redemption reduces in-store strain, and the cadence of engagement ensures freezer space is defended with consistent foot traffic. Retailers enjoy the buzz without the operational burden, driving a seamless flow from pour to prize. Tighten the focus: adopt the single-pint mechanic, ensuring every purchase is a celebration. Stretch the ambition: integrate NFC-enabled coasters for a touchless, tech-savvy experience. This innovation enhances the consumer flow, turning each sip into a seamless blend of tradition and modernity. The commercial payoff is clear: increased sales, heightened engagement, and a story that consumers wear proudly. “Celebrate with Guinness” “Join the team with every pint!”
dealbreakers: Entry is genuinely onerous. This will suppress trial.
Ranging and POS not confirmed yet.

ideationHarness.point: This concept leverages the excitement of surprise and the allure of limited edition collectibles. By introducing a 'Golden Tap' moment, it creates an engaging experience that draws customers into the mystery of potentially winning instant prizes and collecting unique tokens. This taps into consumer love for surprise and anticipation, enhancing the brand's festive appeal during St Patrick's Day.
ideationHarness.move: Deploy the 'Golden Tap' experience in high-traffic Irish pubs, using simple effects to create a glowing tap moment. Promote through digital alerts and an app to notify patrons of their instant win and collectible token, encouraging repeat visits and social sharing.
ideationHarness.risk: The main risk lies in ensuring the technology for the glowing tap and digital alerts works seamlessly to avoid customer frustration. Additionally, the prize and token distribution must be managed to maintain excitement and avoid stock shortages.
ideationHarness.oddsCadence: 1 in 50 pints unlocks a Golden Tap moment; winners receive instant prizes and tokens.
ideationHarness.retailerLine: 'Try your luck with every pint! Will you find the Golden Tap?'

brand.summary: Guinness is a stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in the 18th century. It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

debug.strategist_prompt:
Campaign: Guinness — Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day (Client: Guinness)
Market: AU | Category: Beer | Brand position: DISRUPTOR
BRIEF (facts):
Brand: Guinness | Client: Guinness | Hook: Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day | Mechanic: Buy 12 pints, get a stamp in your Guinness passport for every pint, , walk away with a Guinness T-shirt and your share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Promotion: GWP | GWP: Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse, triggerQty: 12, cap: UNLIMITED | Assured reward: GWP — Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Calendar: St Patrick's Day | Orientation: PAST | RuleFlex: KEEP | Mode: REFLECTIVE (past campaign)
PROMOTRACK (private guardrails & winning patterns):
PROMOTRACK GUARDRAILS (private; do not cite verbatim):
- Hassle: prefer one-screen mobile entry; use QR as a pointer only if natural. Avoid mandatory receipt upload unless clearly warranted.
- Perceived odds (non-assured value only): hero + visible ladder (instant wins and/or weekly moments) usually outperforms single mega-prize.
- Retailer ops: zero staff adjudication; ship pre-packed POS; centralise winner comms & fulfilment.
- Explain-in-5s: staff should pitch in one breath; avoid multi-step or technical terms.
- Compliance (AU default): RSA/ABAC lines for alcohol; age gate; no consumption cues.
- Fulfilment: travel prizes need buffers/concierge; publish timelines in T&Cs.
- KPIs: name ONE primary success metric; align mechanic and value to it.
Use these guardrails to reduce hassle, improve perceived value/odds where relevant, and de-risk store ops. Prefer simple one-screen flows, central adjudication, and clear staff scripts.

Contextual flags:
- Hassle flag: brief suggests receipt/proof handling. Keep it one-screen and simple; only require uploads if value clearly warrants and OCR is seamless.
- Compliance flag (AU alcohol): include RSA/ABAC lines, age gate, and avoid consumption cues.

RuleFlex: KEEP
Apply guardrails strictly; prefer the simplest compliant path; no novelty for novelty’s sake.

Reminder: recommendations must land store-safe (zero staff burden), keep the hook premium and short.
Assured-value mode: do NOT add prize ladders unless a separate overlay is explicitly briefed. Focus on clarity of value, speed, and transparent “how to claim”.

PRIOR FRAMING (authoritative; do not restate):
Where the Demand Is

Autumn in Australia is a key period for beer consumption, particularly with events like St Patrick's Day driving pub attendance. The Australian liquor market is seeing a resurgence in on-premise consumption, with craft beers and authentic experiences gaining traction (Source: nielseniq.com). Guinness, with its strong brand presence, is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend. The focus is on increasing pint velocity and dwell time in pubs during St Patrick's week, aiming for a 12% increase in Guinness draught volume compared to last year (Source: brief).

Who It’s For & What Stops Them

This promotion targets Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout enthusiasts who seek a guaranteed St Patrick's Day story. They value authentic Irish rituals and enjoy collecting Guinness merchandise, wearing it the same night (Source: brief). A key barrier is the cost of living pressures, which influence consumers to seek value in their purchases (Source: drinkstrade.com.au). Another mindset is the social drinker who wants to participate in the Guinness ritual without the hassle of complex promotions.

Competitor Map

Kilkenny and Murphy's are direct competitors, both offering Irish-themed experiences. Kilkenny focuses on enhancing the drinking experience with exclusive deals on glassware, while Murphy's leverages its Irish pub atmosphere (Source: kilkennydesign.com). Local craft stout taps also pose a threat, appealing to consumers seeking unique, locally brewed options. Guinness stands out with its iconic two-part pour and the theatre surrounding its consumption, which competitors struggle to replicate.

Brand Lens (truth, codes to lean/break)

Guinness is synonymous with the theatre of the two-part pour and St Patrick's Day rituals. The brand's rewards program enhances loyalty, offering exclusive experiences and merchandise (Source: guinness.com). Visually, the black pint silhouette and gold harp are distinctive assets. Verbally, phrases like "Made of More" and "Good things come to those who wait" reinforce the brand's premium yet convivial tone. The campaign should lean into authentic Irish experiences and guaranteed value promotions, avoiding generic beer promotions and overused clichés.

The Idea As It Stands

The current promotion involves buying 12 pints of Guinness, collecting stamps in a passport, and redeeming them at the bar for a Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse. This mechanic is designed to drive repeat visits and increase dwell time in pubs. However, the value proposition may need enhancement to meet consumer expectations for assured value.

Proposition Candidates

1. "Buy 12, Wear the Legend" – Emphasize the immediate reward of a Guinness T-shirt.
2. "Sip, Stamp, Score" – Highlight the simplicity and certainty of the reward.
3. "Raise a Pint, Back a Winner" – Connect the Guinness experience with the excitement of backing a racehorse.

Hooks (2–6 words)

Back a Winner
Sip, Stamp, Score
Wear the Legend
Raise a Pint

What We’d Lean On

The campaign should leverage Guinness' distinctive assets, such as the two-part pour and the surge-and-settle cascade. The focus should be on creating a memorable St Patrick's Day experience that aligns with the brand's premium positioning. The assured value of the promotion must be clear and compelling to overcome cost-related barriers.

Hypotheses for Evaluation

1. Increasing the visibility of the Guinness T-shirt as a reward will drive higher engagement.
2. Simplifying the redemption process will enhance participation and repeat visits.
3. Emphasizing the connection between Guinness and the racehorse share will create a unique narrative that differentiates from competitors.

Entry/Redemption (from brief): Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar

The entry mechanic is straightforward, encouraging repeat visits and engagement with the brand. However, the perceived value of the reward should be evaluated to ensure it meets consumer expectations and drives the desired increase in pint velocity.
PRIOR OPINION (authoritative; integrate lightly if still relevant):
As autumn’s golden glow descends on Australia, St Patrick’s Day emerges as a beacon for Guinness, a cultural moment ripe for disruption. The Australian liquor market, robust and thriving, presents a stage where Guinness can dance its two-part pour and cascade its black-and-gold magic. With nearly 70% of Australians indulging in alcohol, the timing is impeccable to capture the hearts and palates of stout enthusiasts (Source: my.nzte.govt.nz). Today, Guinness meets its moment by weaving its brand truth into the fabric of St Patrick’s Day. The promotion promises more than a pint; it offers a story. The Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse are not mere giveaways; they are tangible tokens of pride and participation. Yet, the challenge lies in the high barrier of entry—12 pints—a steep climb in Sydney’s costly beer landscape, 60% pricier than New York (Source: news.com.au). The cultural timing aligns perfectly, but the execution demands a recalibration. Our improvement plan is clear: pivot to a more accessible mechanic. By shifting from 12 pints to a single-pint purchase, we democratize the experience. Each pint becomes a passport, a digital stamp collected with ease. This simplicity not only reduces hassle but aligns with the assured value ethos that Guinness embodies. The Evaluation suggests a premium GWP with explicit RRP, enhancing perceived value and engagement. For retailers, this streamlined approach is a boon. No additional staff lift, no complex adjudication. The digital redemption reduces in-store strain, and the cadence of engagement ensures freezer space is defended with consistent foot traffic. Retailers enjoy the buzz without the operational burden, driving a seamless flow from pour to prize. Tighten the focus: adopt the single-pint mechanic, ensuring every purchase is a celebration. Stretch the ambition: integrate NFC-enabled coasters for a touchless, tech-savvy experience. This innovation enhances the consumer flow, turning each sip into a seamless blend of tradition and modernity. The commercial payoff is clear: increased sales, heightened engagement, and a story that consumers wear proudly. “Celebrate with Guinness” “Join the team with every pint!”
RESEARCH SNAPSHOT (reuse-only; do not fabricate):

RESEARCH INSIGHTS (cite verbatim when useful):
- Brand truth: Guinness has successfully leveraged its distinctive brand voice and consumer insights to become one of Diageo's strongest performers, with a 14% increase in net sales and a notable 24% rise in female drinkers. (warc.com)
- Brand truth: Guinness' rewards program, 'My Guinness', offers exclusive access to experiences and merchandise, enhancing brand loyalty and engagement. (guinness.com)
- Brand truth: Guinness has seen a significant 35% volume growth in Australia, driven by strong on-premise channel performance. (drinkstrade.com.au)
- Shopper tension: Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout fans are seeking memorable St Patrick's Day experiences, creating a demand for unique in-pub promotions and storytelling opportunities. (brief)
- Shopper tension: The cost of living pressures and inflation are impacting alcohol purchasing decisions, with consumers seeking value in their beverage choices. (drinkstrade.com.au)
- Retailer reality: Pubs and hotels are priority retailers for Guinness, emphasizing the importance of on-premise strategies to drive pint velocity during St Patrick's week. (brief)

You must return ONE JSON object ONLY. No preamble, no markdown, no commentary.

Context:
- Audience: Australian brand, shopper, and retail stakeholders.
- Tone: direct, premium, no clichés (“friction”, “prize ladder”). Use plain words like “hassle”, “chances”, “mix of winners”, “on pack”, “in-store”, “POS”.
- The composer will turn this JSON into flowing prose; keep fields tight and specific.

Required top-level fields (all optionality MUST be honoured, but include your best effort):
{
  "stance": string,                           // strategist stance e.g. "BALANCED" | "BOLD" | "CAUTIOUS"
  "brand_position": string,                   // e.g. "LEADER" | "FOLLOWER" | "DISRUPTOR"
  "creative_hook_current": string | null,     // current line on the work/brief
  "creative_hook_better": string | null,      // your sharper, shorter premium line (2–6 words) or null
  "mechanic": string | null,                  // one-liner, e.g. "Buy, scan QR, auto-entry"
  "retailers": string[] | null,               // names where relevant (e.g. "Coles", "BWS")
  "prizes": {                                 // how the win feels
    "hero": string | null,                    // e.g. "Trip for two to Tokyo"
    "hero_count": number | null,              // integer if known
    "hero_value_band": string | null,         // e.g. "$5k–$10k"
    "runner_ups": string[] | null             // titles or shorthand, can be []
  },
  "friction": string | null,                  // free text hints re: hassle (e.g. "receipt upload", "one screen")
  "retailer_ops": {                           // how stores are affected
    "staff_explainable": boolean | null,      // can staff explain it in ~5s?
    "stock_risk": "low"|"medium"|"high"|"unknown" | null,
    "auditability": "low"|"medium"|"high"|"unknown" | null,
    "central_adjudication": boolean | null    // winners handled centrally (preferred)
  },
  "what_worked": string[],                    // short observations (1 line each)
  "what_didnt": string[],                     // short observations (1 line each)
  "risks": string[],                          // e.g. "people drop at proof upload"
  "fixes": string[],                          // practical changes in plain words

  // Narrative drivers for the composer (use tight, specific lines)
  "ferrier_bets": string[],                   // behavioural bets (cut hassle, habit, social proof, etc.)
  "droga_bets": string[],                     // fame bets (two-word line, talkability, distinctive assets)

  // PromoTrack
  "promotrack_applied": string[],             // play names actually leaned on (use canonical names if provided)
  "promotrack_rejected": string[],            // plays considered then parked (with a 2–5 word reason appended, if useful)

  // Judgement drives verdict tone in the composer
  "judgement": {
    "verdict": "GO" | "GO_WITH_CONDITIONS" | "NO-GO",
    "because": string                        // one-breath reason, one sentence
  },

  // Optional rebuild spec. Keep lines short; composer will render.
  "rebuild_spec": {
    "hook_line": string | null,
    "hooks": string[] | null,                 // alternates, short premium lines
    "entry_path": string | null,              // plain, e.g. "QR → one quick mobile screen → auto-entry"
    "cadence": string | null,                 // e.g. "Weekly prize moments + final hero"
    "ladder": any | null,                     // ignore structure; composer will describe as “mix of winners”
    "fulfilment": string | null,              // how winners are handled; keep stores out
    "compliance_line": string | null,         // RSA/ABAC or standard guardrails
    "staff_script": string | null             // 5-second in-store script
  },

  // Optionally propose one or more bolder takes (rule-bending)
  "bold_variants": [
    {
      "name": string | null,                  // e.g. "Two-word fame line + instant-win wall"
      "idea": string | null,
      "hypothesis": string | null,
      "risks": string[] | null,
      "mitigations": string[] | null,
      "measures": string[] | null,            // how we’ll judge it (metrics/observables)
      "exit": string | null                   // when to pull the pin
    }
  ]
}

// Rules:
- Keep strings concise. Prefer one sentence per item.
- Stay Australian in wording. Avoid buzzwords where a plain phrase works.
- If a field is unknown, set it to null or [] as appropriate.
- Do not output headings, markdown, or commentary — return JSON only.

Framing (authoritative; do not restate, use to inform tone):
Where the Demand Is

Autumn in Australia is a key period for beer consumption, particularly with events like St Patrick's Day driving pub attendance. The Australian liquor market is seeing a resurgence in on-premise consumption, with craft beers and authentic experiences gaining traction (Source: nielseniq.com). Guinness, with its strong brand presence, is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend. The focus is on increasing pint velocity and dwell time in pubs during St Patrick's week, aiming for a 12% increase in Guinness draught volume compared to last year (Source: brief).

Who It’s For & What Stops Them

This promotion targets Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout enthusiasts who seek a guaranteed St Patrick's Day story. They value authentic Irish rituals and enjoy collecting Guinness merchandise, wearing it the same night (Source: brief). A key barrier is the cost of living pressures, which influence consumers to seek value in their purchases (Source: drinkstrade.com.au). Another mindset is the social drinker who wants to participate in the Guinness ritual without the hassle of complex promotions.

Competitor Map

Kilkenny and Murphy's are direct competitors, both offering Irish-themed experiences. Kilkenny focuses on enhancing the drinking experience with exclusive deals on glassware, while Murphy's leverages its Irish pub atmosphere (Source: kilkennydesign.com). Local craft stout taps also pose a threat, appealing to consumers seeking unique, locally brewed options. Guinness stands out with its iconic two-part pour and the theatre surrounding its consumption, which competitors struggle to replicate.

Brand Lens (truth, codes to lean/break)

Guinness is synonymous with the theatre of the two-part pour and St Patrick's Day rituals. The brand's rewards program enhances loyalty, offering exclusive experiences and merchandise (Source: guinness.com). Visually, the black pint silhouette and gold harp are distinctive assets. Verbally, phrases like "Made of More" and "Good things come to those who wait" reinforce the brand's premium yet convivial tone. The campaign should lean into authentic Irish experiences and guaranteed value promotions, avoiding generic beer promotions and overused clichés.

The Idea As It Stands

The current promotion involves buying 12 pints of Guinness, collecting stamps in a passport, and redeeming them at the bar for a Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse. This mechanic is designed to drive repeat visits and increase dwell time in pubs. However, the value proposition may need enhancement to meet consumer expectations for assured value.

Proposition Candidates

1. "Buy 12, Wear the Legend" – Emphasize the immediate reward of a Guinness T-shirt.
2. "Sip, Stamp, Score" – Highlight the simplicity and certainty of the reward.
3. "Raise a Pint, Back a Winner" – Connect the Guinness experience with the excitement of backing a racehorse.

Hooks (2–6 words)

Back a Winner
Sip, Stamp, Score
Wear the Legend
Raise a Pint

What We’d Lean On

The campaign should leverage Guinness' distinctive assets, such as the two-part pour and the surge-and-settle cascade. The focus should be on creating a memorable St Patrick's Day experience that aligns with the brand's premium positioning. The assured value of the promotion must be clear and compelling to overcome cost-related barriers.

Hypotheses for Evaluation

1. Increasing the visibility of the Guinness T-shirt as a reward will drive higher engagement.
2. Simplifying the redemption process will enhance participation and repeat visits.
3. Emphasizing the connection between Guinness and the racehorse share will create a unique narrative that differentiates from competitors.

Entry/Redemption (from brief): Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar

The entry mechanic is straightforward, encouraging repeat visits and engagement with the brand. However, the perceived value of the reward should be evaluated to ensure it

Each run_again_moves item must be 6–12 words, brand-aligned, and actionable (e.g., "Digitise passport stamp via NFC coaster"). Never introduce prize pools or mechanics that contradict the briefed mechanic.

Why it works — max two sentences tying brand truth, shopper tension, and timing.
Where it breaks — max two sentences naming the hardest flaws.
Fix it — max two sentences with the concrete plan to repair those flaws.

It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

ui.priorOpinion: As autumn’s golden glow descends on Australia, St Patrick’s Day emerges as a beacon for Guinness, a cultural moment ripe for disruption. The Australian liquor market, robust and thriving, presents a stage where Guinness can dance its two-part pour and cascade its black-and-gold magic. With nearly 70% of Australians indulging in alcohol, the timing is impeccable to capture the hearts and palates of stout enthusiasts (Source: my.nzte.govt.nz). Today, Guinness meets its moment by weaving its brand truth into the fabric of St Patrick’s Day. The promotion promises more than a pint; it offers a story. The Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse are not mere giveaways; they are tangible tokens of pride and participation. Yet, the challenge lies in the high barrier of entry—12 pints—a steep climb in Sydney’s costly beer landscape, 60% pricier than New York (Source: news.com.au). The cultural timing aligns perfectly, but the execution demands a recalibration. Our improvement plan is clear: pivot to a more accessible mechanic. By shifting from 12 pints to a single-pint purchase, we democratize the experience. Each pint becomes a passport, a digital stamp collected with ease. This simplicity not only reduces hassle but aligns with the assured value ethos that Guinness embodies. The Evaluation suggests a premium GWP with explicit RRP, enhancing perceived value and engagement. For retailers, this streamlined approach is a boon. No additional staff lift, no complex adjudication. The digital redemption reduces in-store strain, and the cadence of engagement ensures freezer space is defended with consistent foot traffic. Retailers enjoy the buzz without the operational burden, driving a seamless flow from pour to prize. Tighten the focus: adopt the single-pint mechanic, ensuring every purchase is a celebration. Stretch the ambition: integrate NFC-enabled coasters for a touchless, tech-savvy experience. This innovation enhances the consumer flow, turning each sip into a seamless blend of tradition and modernity. The commercial payoff is clear: increased sales, heightened engagement, and a story that consumers wear proudly. “Celebrate with Guinness” “Join the team with every pint!”
dealbreakers: Entry is genuinely onerous. This will suppress trial.
Ranging and POS not confirmed yet.

ideationHarness.point: This concept leverages the excitement of surprise and the allure of limited edition collectibles. By introducing a 'Golden Tap' moment, it creates an engaging experience that draws customers into the mystery of potentially winning instant prizes and collecting unique tokens. This taps into consumer love for surprise and anticipation, enhancing the brand's festive appeal during St Patrick's Day.
ideationHarness.move: Deploy the 'Golden Tap' experience in high-traffic Irish pubs, using simple effects to create a glowing tap moment. Promote through digital alerts and an app to notify patrons of their instant win and collectible token, encouraging repeat visits and social sharing.
ideationHarness.risk: The main risk lies in ensuring the technology for the glowing tap and digital alerts works seamlessly to avoid customer frustration. Additionally, the prize and token distribution must be managed to maintain excitement and avoid stock shortages.
ideationHarness.oddsCadence: 1 in 50 pints unlocks a Golden Tap moment; winners receive instant prizes and tokens.
ideationHarness.retailerLine: 'Try your luck with every pint! Will you find the Golden Tap?'

Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.

debug.strategist_prompt:
Campaign: Guinness — Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day (Client: Guinness)
Market: AU | Category: Beer | Brand position: DISRUPTOR
BRIEF (facts):
Brand: Guinness | Client: Guinness | Hook: Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day | Mechanic: Buy 12 pints, get a stamp in your Guinness passport for every pint, , walk away with a Guinness T-shirt and your share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Promotion: GWP | GWP: Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse, triggerQty: 12, cap: UNLIMITED | Assured reward: GWP — Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Calendar: St Patrick's Day | Orientation: PAST | RuleFlex: KEEP | Mode: REFLECTIVE (past campaign)
PROMOTRACK (private guardrails & winning patterns):
PROMOTRACK GUARDRAILS (private; do not cite verbatim):
- Hassle: prefer one-screen mobile entry; use QR as a pointer only if natural. Avoid mandatory receipt upload unless clearly warranted.
- Perceived odds (non-assured value only): hero + visible ladder (instant wins and/or weekly moments) usually outperforms single mega-prize.
- Retailer ops: zero staff adjudication; ship pre-packed POS; centralise winner comms & fulfilment.
- Explain-in-5s: staff should pitch in one breath; avoid multi-step or technical terms.
- Compliance (AU default): RSA/ABAC lines for alcohol; age gate; no consumption cues.
- Fulfilment: travel prizes need buffers/concierge; publish timelines in T&Cs.
- KPIs: name ONE primary success metric; align mechanic and value to it.
Use these guardrails to reduce hassle, improve perceived value/odds where relevant, and de-risk store ops. Prefer simple one-screen flows, central adjudication, and clear staff scripts.

Contextual flags:
- Hassle flag: brief suggests receipt/proof handling. Keep it one-screen and simple; only require uploads if value clearly warrants and OCR is seamless.
- Compliance flag (AU alcohol): include RSA/ABAC lines, age gate, and avoid consumption cues.

RuleFlex: KEEP
Apply guardrails strictly; prefer the simplest compliant path; no novelty for novelty’s sake.

Reminder: recommendations must land store-safe (zero staff burden), keep the hook premium and short.
Assured-value mode: do NOT add prize ladders unless a separate overlay is explicitly briefed. Focus on clarity of value, speed, and transparent “how to claim”.

PRIOR FRAMING (authoritative; do not restate):
Where the Demand Is

Autumn in Australia is a key period for beer consumption, particularly with events like St Patrick's Day driving pub attendance. The Australian liquor market is seeing a resurgence in on-premise consumption, with craft beers and authentic experiences gaining traction (Source: nielseniq.com). Guinness, with its strong brand presence, is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend. The focus is on increasing pint velocity and dwell time in pubs during St Patrick's week, aiming for a 12% increase in Guinness draught volume compared to last year (Source: brief).

Who It’s For & What Stops Them

This promotion targets Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout enthusiasts who seek a guaranteed St Patrick's Day story. They value authentic Irish rituals and enjoy collecting Guinness merchandise, wearing it the same night (Source: brief). A key barrier is the cost of living pressures, which influence consumers to seek value in their purchases (Source: drinkstrade.com.au). Another mindset is the social drinker who wants to participate in the Guinness ritual without the hassle of complex promotions.

Competitor Map

Kilkenny and Murphy's are direct competitors, both offering Irish-themed experiences. Kilkenny focuses on enhancing the drinking experience with exclusive deals on glassware, while Murphy's leverages its Irish pub atmosphere (Source: kilkennydesign.com). Local craft stout taps also pose a threat, appealing to consumers seeking unique, locally brewed options. Guinness stands out with its iconic two-part pour and the theatre surrounding its consumption, which competitors struggle to replicate.

Brand Lens (truth, codes to lean/break)

Guinness is synonymous with the theatre of the two-part pour and St Patrick's Day rituals. The brand's rewards program enhances loyalty, offering exclusive experiences and merchandise (Source: guinness.com). Visually, the black pint silhouette and gold harp are distinctive assets. Verbally, phrases like "Made of More" and "Good things come to those who wait" reinforce the brand's premium yet convivial tone. The campaign should lean into authentic Irish experiences and guaranteed value promotions, avoiding generic beer promotions and overused clichés.

The Idea As It Stands

The current promotion involves buying 12 pints of Guinness, collecting stamps in a passport, and redeeming them at the bar for a Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse. This mechanic is designed to drive repeat visits and increase dwell time in pubs. However, the value proposition may need enhancement to meet consumer expectations for assured value.

Proposition Candidates

1. "Buy 12, Wear the Legend" – Emphasize the immediate reward of a Guinness T-shirt.
2. "Sip, Stamp, Score" – Highlight the simplicity and certainty of the reward.
3. "Raise a Pint, Back a Winner" – Connect the Guinness experience with the excitement of backing a racehorse.

Hooks (2–6 words)

Back a Winner
Sip, Stamp, Score
Wear the Legend
Raise a Pint

What We’d Lean On

The campaign should leverage Guinness' distinctive assets, such as the two-part pour and the surge-and-settle cascade. The focus should be on creating a memorable St Patrick's Day experience that aligns with the brand's premium positioning. The assured value of the promotion must be clear and compelling to overcome cost-related barriers.

Hypotheses for Evaluation

1. Increasing the visibility of the Guinness T-shirt as a reward will drive higher engagement.
2. Simplifying the redemption process will enhance participation and repeat visits.
3. Emphasizing the connection between Guinness and the racehorse share will create a unique narrative that differentiates from competitors.

Entry/Redemption (from brief): Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar

The entry mechanic is straightforward, encouraging repeat visits and engagement with the brand. However, the perceived value of the reward should be evaluated to ensure it meets consumer expectations and drives the desired increase in pint velocity.
PRIOR OPINION (authoritative; integrate lightly if still relevant):
As autumn’s golden glow descends on Australia, St Patrick’s Day emerges as a beacon for Guinness, a cultural moment ripe for disruption. The Australian liquor market, robust and thriving, presents a stage where Guinness can dance its two-part pour and cascade its black-and-gold magic. With nearly 70% of Australians indulging in alcohol, the timing is impeccable to capture the hearts and palates of stout enthusiasts (Source: my.nzte.govt.nz). Today, Guinness meets its moment by weaving its brand truth into the fabric of St Patrick’s Day. The promotion promises more than a pint; it offers a story. The Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse are not mere giveaways; they are tangible tokens of pride and participation. Yet, the challenge lies in the high barrier of entry—12 pints—a steep climb in Sydney’s costly beer landscape, 60% pricier than New York (Source: news.com.au). The cultural timing aligns perfectly, but the execution demands a recalibration. Our improvement plan is clear: pivot to a more accessible mechanic. By shifting from 12 pints to a single-pint purchase, we democratize the experience. Each pint becomes a passport, a digital stamp collected with ease. This simplicity not only reduces hassle but aligns with the assured value ethos that Guinness embodies. The Evaluation suggests a premium GWP with explicit RRP, enhancing perceived value and engagement. For retailers, this streamlined approach is a boon. No additional staff lift, no complex adjudication. The digital redemption reduces in-store strain, and the cadence of engagement ensures freezer space is defended with consistent foot traffic. Retailers enjoy the buzz without the operational burden, driving a seamless flow from pour to prize. Tighten the focus: adopt the single-pint mechanic, ensuring every purchase is a celebration. Stretch the ambition: integrate NFC-enabled coasters for a touchless, tech-savvy experience. This innovation enhances the consumer flow, turning each sip into a seamless blend of tradition and modernity. The commercial payoff is clear: increased sales, heightened engagement, and a story that consumers wear proudly. “Celebrate with Guinness” “Join the team with every pint!”
RESEARCH SNAPSHOT (reuse-only; do not fabricate):

RESEARCH INSIGHTS (cite verbatim when useful):
- Brand truth: Guinness has successfully leveraged its distinctive brand voice and consumer insights to become one of Diageo's strongest performers, with a 14% increase in net sales and a notable 24% rise in female drinkers. (warc.com)
- Brand truth: Guinness' rewards program, 'My Guinness', offers exclusive access to experiences and merchandise, enhancing brand loyalty and engagement. (guinness.com)
- Brand truth: Guinness has seen a significant 35% volume growth in Australia, driven by strong on-premise channel performance. (drinkstrade.com.au)
- Shopper tension: Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout fans are seeking memorable St Patrick's Day experiences, creating a demand for unique in-pub promotions and storytelling opportunities. (brief)
- Shopper tension: The cost of living pressures and inflation are impacting alcohol purchasing decisions, with consumers seeking value in their beverage choices. (drinkstrade.com.au)
- Retailer reality: Pubs and hotels are priority retailers for Guinness, emphasizing the importance of on-premise strategies to drive pint velocity during St Patrick's week. (brief)

You must return ONE JSON object ONLY. No preamble, no markdown, no commentary.

Context:
- Audience: Australian brand, shopper, and retail stakeholders.
- Tone: direct, premium, no clichés (“friction”, “prize ladder”). Use plain words like “hassle”, “chances”, “mix of winners”, “on pack”, “in-store”, “POS”.
- The composer will turn this JSON into flowing prose; keep fields tight and specific.

Required top-level fields (all optionality MUST be honoured, but include your best effort):
{
  "stance": string,                           // strategist stance e.g. "BALANCED" | "BOLD" | "CAUTIOUS"
  "brand_position": string,                   // e.g. "LEADER" | "FOLLOWER" | "DISRUPTOR"
  "creative_hook_current": string | null,     // current line on the work/brief
  "creative_hook_better": string | null,      // your sharper, shorter premium line (2–6 words) or null
  "mechanic": string | null,                  // one-liner, e.g. "Buy, scan QR, auto-entry"
  "retailers": string[] | null,               // names where relevant (e.g. "Coles", "BWS")
  "prizes": {                                 // how the win feels
    "hero": string | null,                    // e.g. "Trip for two to Tokyo"
    "hero_count": number | null,              // integer if known
    "hero_value_band": string | null,         // e.g. "$5k–$10k"
    "runner_ups": string[] | null             // titles or shorthand, can be []
  },
  "friction": string | null,                  // free text hints re: hassle (e.g. "receipt upload", "one screen")
  "retailer_ops": {                           // how stores are affected
    "staff_explainable": boolean | null,      // can staff explain it in ~5s?
    "stock_risk": "low"|"medium"|"high"|"unknown" | null,
    "auditability": "low"|"medium"|"high"|"unknown" | null,
    "central_adjudication": boolean | null    // winners handled centrally (preferred)
  },
  "what_worked": string[],                    // short observations (1 line each)
  "what_didnt": string[],                     // short observations (1 line each)
  "risks": string[],                          // e.g. "people drop at proof upload"
  "fixes": string[],                          // practical changes in plain words

  // Narrative drivers for the composer (use tight, specific lines)
  "ferrier_bets": string[],                   // behavioural bets (cut hassle, habit, social proof, etc.)
  "droga_bets": string[],                     // fame bets (two-word line, talkability, distinctive assets)

  // PromoTrack
  "promotrack_applied": string[],             // play names actually leaned on (use canonical names if provided)
  "promotrack_rejected": string[],            // plays considered then parked (with a 2–5 word reason appended, if useful)

  // Judgement drives verdict tone in the composer
  "judgement": {
    "verdict": "GO" | "GO_WITH_CONDITIONS" | "NO-GO",
    "because": string                        // one-breath reason, one sentence
  },

  // Optional rebuild spec. Keep lines short; composer will render.
  "rebuild_spec": {
    "hook_line": string | null,
    "hooks": string[] | null,                 // alternates, short premium lines
    "entry_path": string | null,              // plain, e.g. "QR → one quick mobile screen → auto-entry"
    "cadence": string | null,                 // e.g. "Weekly prize moments + final hero"
    "ladder": any | null,                     // ignore structure; composer will describe as “mix of winners”
    "fulfilment": string | null,              // how winners are handled; keep stores out
    "compliance_line": string | null,         // RSA/ABAC or standard guardrails
    "staff_script": string | null             // 5-second in-store script
  },

  // Optionally propose one or more bolder takes (rule-bending)
  "bold_variants": [
    {
      "name": string | null,                  // e.g. "Two-word fame line + instant-win wall"
      "idea": string | null,
      "hypothesis": string | null,
      "risks": string[] | null,
      "mitigations": string[] | null,
      "measures": string[] | null,            // how we’ll judge it (metrics/observables)
      "exit": string | null                   // when to pull the pin
    }
  ]
}

// Rules:
- Keep strings concise. Prefer one sentence per item.
- Stay Australian in wording. Avoid buzzwords where a plain phrase works.
- If a field is unknown, set it to null or [] as appropriate.
- Do not output headings, markdown, or commentary — return JSON only.

// Example (illustrative only):
{
  "stance": "BALANCED",
  "brand_position": "FOLLOWER",
  "creative_hook_current": "Win the ultimate summer escape",
  "creative_hook_better": "Own Your Summer",
  "mechanic": "Buy any 2, scan the QR, auto-entry",
  "retailers": ["Coles", "Woolworths"],
  "prizes": {
    "hero": "Beach house weekender",
    "hero_count": 3,
    "hero_value_band": "$5k–$10k",
    "runner_ups": ["$100 gift cards", "Cooler bags"]
  },
  "friction": "Receipt upload mentioned; prefer one quick mobile screen",
  "retailer_ops": {
    "staff_explainable": true,
    "stock_risk": "low",
    "auditability": "high",
    "central_adjudication": true
  },
  "what_worked": ["Seasonal timing is spot on", "Brand assets are recognisable on pack"],
  "what_didnt": ["Line is long and functional", "Chances feel thin without more winners"],
  "risks": ["People will bail at proof step", "Travel fulfilment can drag if unclear"],
  "fixes": ["Lose proof upload", "Add instant wins and weekly draws", "Publish total number of winners"],

  "ferrier_bets": ["Cut the hassle to one clear mobile action", "Show a weekly rhythm so there’s a reason to come back"],
  "droga_bets": ["Two-word fame line on pack", "Make the moment worth filming"],

  "promotrack_applied": ["Weekly micro-win cadence", "Central adjudication", "Pre-packed POS kits"],
  "promotrack_rejected": ["Price-off lookalike — wrong signal", "Receipt upload — too much hassle"],

  "judgement": { "verdict": "GO_WITH_CONDITIONS", "because": "Great seasonal frame; tighten the line and make entry fast, with more visible winners." },

  "rebuild_spec": {
    "hook_line": "Own Your Summer",
    "hooks": ["Own Your Summer", "Make Summer Yours"],
    "entry_path": "QR → one quick mobile screen → auto-entry",
    "cadence": "Weekly prize moments plus a final hero",
    "ladder": {},
    "fulfilment": "Winners contacted centrally; no store adjudication",
    "compliance_line": "Standard trade promo; if alcohol present, age gate and no consumption cues",
    "staff_script": "Scan the QR on the pack and you’re in — takes 20 seconds."
  },

  "bold_variants": [
    {
      "name": "Two-word fame line + instant-win wall",
      "idea": "A physical POS wall where packs light up instant wins when scanned",
      "hypothesis": "In-store theatre drives talkability and repeat",
      "risks": ["Operational set-up", "POS maintenance"],
      "mitigations": ["Pilot in top 20 stores", "Dedicated merch support"],
      "measures": ["Scan rate per store", "Repeat scans per shopper", "Lift vs control banners"],
      "exit": "If scan rate <50/day after week one, roll back to static POS"
    }
  ]
}

Additions:
- hook_why_change: string (what exactly is wrong with the *current* hook).
- symbolism: string[] (≤5) if a clear cultural/national bridge exists.
- proposition_hint: string if a tight commercial line is clear.
- trade_priority: "HIGH"|"LOW". Set "trade_priority":"LOW" and omit "trade_table". Do not fabricate trade advice.
- run_again_moves: string[] (≤5) — concrete changes if we ran this again.
Rules:
- Do NOT invent retailer names or numbers.
- If a value is unknown, use null or [].
- Tie WHY/FIX statements to this campaign’s facts wherever possible.
- Do NOT recommend cashback unless it already appears in BRIEF.
- Return ONLY a valid JSON object.

Campaign: Guinness — Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day (Client: Guinness)
Market: AU | Category: Beer | Mode: REFLECTIVE
AssuredMode: ASSURED_VALUE
Verdict to uphold: NO-GO
Facts:
Brand: Guinness | Client: Guinness | Hook: Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day | Mechanic: Buy 12 pints, get a stamp in your Guinness passport for every pint, , walk away with a Guinness T-shirt and your share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Promotion: GWP | GWP: Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse, triggerQty: 12, cap: UNLIMITED | Assured reward: GWP — Branded t-shirt, one share in Sir Guinness the racehorse | Calendar: St Patrick's Day | Orientation: PAST | RuleFlex: KEEP | Mode: REFLECTIVE (past campaign)
Operational guardrails: Store teams have zero capacity — no staff-run announcements, kiosks, or manual verification. Keep cadence visible through consumer-facing messaging (pack, digital, social), not store labour. Never suggest staff-run amplification, kiosks, or in-store terminals — execution must run on consumer comms and zero additional store labour.
Briefed entry mechanic: Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar. Keep the plan anchored in this flow.
CREATE_UNBOXED / BRUCE focus:
- Hook: Guinness Golden Taps & Tokens
- Point: This concept leverages the excitement of surprise and the allure of limited edition collectibles. By introducing a 'Golden Tap' moment, it creates an engaging experience that draws customers into the mystery of potentially winning instant prizes and collecting unique tokens. This taps into consumer love for surprise and anticipation, enhancing the brand's festive appeal during St Patrick's Day.
- Move: Deploy the 'Golden Tap' experience in high-traffic Irish pubs, using simple effects to create a glowing tap moment. Promote through digital alerts and an app to notify patrons of their instant win and collectible token, encouraging repeat visits and social sharing.
- Risk: The main risk lies in ensuring the technology for the glowing tap and digital alerts works seamlessly to avoid customer frustration. Additionally, the prize and token distribution must be managed to maintain excitement and avoid stock shortages.
- Odds & cadence: 1 in 50 pints unlocks a Golden Tap moment; winners receive instant prizes and tokens.
- Retailer line: 'Try your luck with every pint! Will you find the Golden Tap?'
Research hints:
Brand truth: Guinness has successfully leveraged its distinctive brand voice and consumer insights to become one of Diageo's strongest performers, with a 14% increase in net sales and a notable 24% rise in female drinkers. (warc.com) | Brand truth: Guinness' rewards program, 'My Guinness', offers exclusive access to experiences and merchandise, enhancing brand loyalty and engagement. (guinness.com) | Brand truth: Guinness has seen a significant 35% volume growth in Australia, driven by strong on-premise channel performance. (drinkstrade.com.au) | Shopper tension: Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout fans are seeking memorable St Patrick's Day experiences, creating a demand for unique in-pub promotions and storytelling opportunities. (brief) | Shopper tension: The cost of living pressures and inflation are impacting alcohol purchasing decisions, with consumers seeking value in their beverage choices. (drinkstrade.com.au) | Retailer reality: Pubs and hotels are priority retailers for Guinness, emphasizing the importance of on-premise strategies to drive pint velocity during St Patrick's week. Recommended hero-prize count: 2 (perceived odds; invest remainder into breadth/instants).
Framing (authoritative; do not restate, use to inform tone):
Where the Demand Is

Autumn in Australia is a key period for beer consumption, particularly with events like St Patrick's Day driving pub attendance. The Australian liquor market is seeing a resurgence in on-premise consumption, with craft beers and authentic experiences gaining traction (Source: nielseniq.com). Guinness, with its strong brand presence, is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend. The focus is on increasing pint velocity and dwell time in pubs during St Patrick's week, aiming for a 12% increase in Guinness draught volume compared to last year (Source: brief).

Who It’s For & What Stops Them

This promotion targets Irish-leaning pub regulars and stout enthusiasts who seek a guaranteed St Patrick's Day story. They value authentic Irish rituals and enjoy collecting Guinness merchandise, wearing it the same night (Source: brief). A key barrier is the cost of living pressures, which influence consumers to seek value in their purchases (Source: drinkstrade.com.au). Another mindset is the social drinker who wants to participate in the Guinness ritual without the hassle of complex promotions.

Competitor Map

Kilkenny and Murphy's are direct competitors, both offering Irish-themed experiences. Kilkenny focuses on enhancing the drinking experience with exclusive deals on glassware, while Murphy's leverages its Irish pub atmosphere (Source: kilkennydesign.com). Local craft stout taps also pose a threat, appealing to consumers seeking unique, locally brewed options. Guinness stands out with its iconic two-part pour and the theatre surrounding its consumption, which competitors struggle to replicate.

Brand Lens (truth, codes to lean/break)

Guinness is synonymous with the theatre of the two-part pour and St Patrick's Day rituals. The brand's rewards program enhances loyalty, offering exclusive experiences and merchandise (Source: guinness.com). Visually, the black pint silhouette and gold harp are distinctive assets. Verbally, phrases like "Made of More" and "Good things come to those who wait" reinforce the brand's premium yet convivial tone. The campaign should lean into authentic Irish experiences and guaranteed value promotions, avoiding generic beer promotions and overused clichés.

The Idea As It Stands

The current promotion involves buying 12 pints of Guinness, collecting stamps in a passport, and redeeming them at the bar for a Guinness T-shirt and a share in Sir Guinness the racehorse. This mechanic is designed to drive repeat visits and increase dwell time in pubs. However, the value proposition may need enhancement to meet consumer expectations for assured value.

Proposition Candidates

1. "Buy 12, Wear the Legend" – Emphasize the immediate reward of a Guinness T-shirt.
2. "Sip, Stamp, Score" – Highlight the simplicity and certainty of the reward.
3. "Raise a Pint, Back a Winner" – Connect the Guinness experience with the excitement of backing a racehorse.

Hooks (2–6 words)

Back a Winner
Sip, Stamp, Score
Wear the Legend
Raise a Pint

What We’d Lean On

The campaign should leverage Guinness' distinctive assets, such as the two-part pour and the surge-and-settle cascade. The focus should be on creating a memorable St Patrick's Day experience that aligns with the brand's premium positioning. The assured value of the promotion must be clear and compelling to overcome cost-related barriers.

Hypotheses for Evaluation

1. Increasing the visibility of the Guinness T-shirt as a reward will drive higher engagement.
2. Simplifying the redemption process will enhance participation and repeat visits.
3. Emphasizing the connection between Guinness and the racehorse share will create a unique narrative that differentiates from competitors.

Entry/Redemption (from brief): Buy 12 pints of Guinness, collect stamps in your passport, redeem at the bar

The entry mechanic is straightforward, encouraging repeat visits and engagement with the brand. However, the perceived value of the reward should be evaluated to ensure it

ideationHarness.point: This concept leverages the excitement of surprise and the allure of limited edition collectibles. By introducing a 'Golden Tap' moment, it creates an engaging experience that draws customers into the mystery of potentially winning instant prizes and collecting unique tokens. This taps into consumer love for surprise and anticipation, enhancing the brand's festive appeal during St Patrick's Day.
ideationHarness.move: Deploy the 'Golden Tap' experience in high-traffic Irish pubs, using simple effects to create a glowing tap moment. Promote through digital alerts and an app to notify patrons of their instant win and collectible token, encouraging repeat visits and social sharing.
ideationHarness.risk: The main risk lies in ensuring the technology for the glowing tap and digital alerts works seamlessly to avoid customer frustration. Additionally, the prize and token distribution must be managed to maintain excitement and avoid stock shortages.
ideationHarness.oddsCadence: 1 in 50 pints unlocks a Golden Tap moment; winners receive instant prizes and tokens.
ideationHarness.retailerLine: 'Try your luck with every pint! Will you find the Golden Tap?'

atAGlance.label: Objective fit
atAGlance.why: Objective not crisply named or spread across too many aims.
atAGlance.fix: Change-from: diffuse aims. → Change-to: one KPI (e.g., +8–12% ROS) and shape comms/value to it.

atAGlance.label: Hook strength
atAGlance.why: Hook exists (“Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day”) but needs tightening and brand-locking; a sharper variant is proposed (“Raise a Pint, Back a Winner”).
atAGlance.fix: Change-from: long/soft hook (“Back a Winner This St Patrick's Day”). → Change-to: 2–6 words, brand-locked, used on pack and the first screen.

atAGlance.label: Entry mechanic
atAGlance.why: Mechanic defined: Buy 12 pints, collect stamps, redeem for T-shirt and racehorse share.

atAGlance.label: Repeat potential
atAGlance.why: Repeat rhythm not explicit for this format.
atAGlance.fix: Change-from: one-and-done feel. → Change-to: a light cadence of confirmation/membership moments (no prize draws).

atAGlance.label: Hassle to enter
atAGlance.why: Entry is genuinely onerous. This will suppress trial.
atAGlance.fix: Remove mail-in / first-step proof / multi-upload. Make first touch minimal; shift verification post-entry.

atAGlance.label: How the value feels
atAGlance.why: Guaranteed gift-with-purchase (no artificial scarcity stated).

atAGlance.label: Retailer readiness
atAGlance.why: Ranging and POS not confirmed yet.
atAGlance.fix: Change-from: no retailer plan. → Change-to: confirm banners; ship POS kits; zero staff workload.

atAGlance.label: Compliance risk
atAGlance.why: RSA/ABAC sensitivities likely in AU.
atAGlance.fix: Change-from: implied RSA risk. → Change-to: age gate, RSA/ABAC lines, no consumption cues, moderation plan.

atAGlance.label: Fulfilment
atAGlance.why: Central fulfilment looks straightforward.

atAGlance.label: KPI realism
atAGlance.why: Entry band not named; prize/media not back-solved to that range.
atAGlance.fix: Change-from: no entry band. → Change-to: set range, back-solve media and ops to it.

adequacy.fix: Change-from: $0 on ~$20. → Change-to: ≥$42 or ≥10% of ASP, or pivot to a premium GWP with clear RRP.

simplicity.why: Some admin implied (fields/proof or wait time).
simplicity.fix: Keep claim one-screen; limit fields; good OCR; publish timelines.

certainty.fix: Fix adequacy first; certainty only works if value feels worth it.

salience.why: Number reads small; lacks stopping power.
salience.fix: Round up or pivot to premium GWP with explicit RRP.

talkability.fix: Add a brand-right experiential or symbolic angle.

retailerFit.why: Ensure any adjudication is central; ship pre-packed POS.
retailerFit.fix: Keep staff script ≤5s; no in-store adjudication.

brandFit.fix: Lock line and visuals to distinctive assets and the brand’s functional truth.

brand.summary: Guinness is a stout that originated in the brewery of Arthur Guinness at St. James's Gate, Dublin, Ireland, in the 18th century. It is now owned by the British multinational alcoholic beverage maker Diageo. It is one of the most successful alcohol brands worldwide, brewed in almost 50 countries, and available in over 120. Sales in 2011 amounted to 850,000,000 litres. It is the highest-selling beer in both Ireland and the United Kingdom.

category.summary: Beer is an alcoholic beverage produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches from cereal grain—most commonly malted barley, although wheat, maize, rice, and oats are also used. The grain is mashed to convert starch in the grain to sugars, which dissolve in water to form wort. Fermentation of the wort by yeast produces ethanol and carbonation in the beer. Beer is one of the oldest and most widely consumed alcoholic drinks in the world, and one of the most popular of all drinks. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent. Other flavouring agents, such as gruit, herbs, or fruits, may be included or used instead of hops. In commercial brewing, natural carbonation is often replaced with forced carbonation.
